questions.text: The drug increasing uveoscleral flow is?

True regarding POAG: Abnormality of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy First degree relatives have more chances of developing steroid induced glaucoma Dilatation of pupil is associated with exacerbation of IOP First degree relatives are at 1% increased risk of POAG Visual field defect can exist with normal C:D ratio
In a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma, which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most commonly seen?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Marcus Gunn pupil

  • Optic neuritis
  • Optic neuropathy
  • Chiasmal compression
  • Intraocular hemorrhage
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Retinal detachment
  • Optic tract lesion
  • Central or branch arterial occlusion
  • Central or branch vein occlusion
  • Anisometropic amblyopia
  • Cataract
  • Corneal scar
  • Visual pathway damage

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 2-month-old infant who was brought in by their mother due to complaints of light sensitivity, difficulty opening the eyes, and excessive tearing?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma:

Types
  1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

questions.text: Which medication should be avoided in a 30-year-old female presenting with redness, pain, increased intraocular pressure, keratic precipitates, and aqueous flare?
questions.explanation:
Prostaglandin Analogues:

Latanoprost, Bimatoprost, Travoprost, Tafluprost

Mechanism:

Increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Sandy eyes, orbital fat atrophy, anterior uveitis, cystoid macular edema, heterochromia iridis, hypertrichosis

Contraindications:

Cystoid macular edema, diabetes mellitus, Anterior Uveitis (Option D)

Beta Blockers: (Option A)

  • Non-Selective: Timolol, Levobunolol, Carteolol, Metipranolol
  • Selective: Betaxolol, Levobetaxolol

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis, dry eyes, corneal hypoesthesia

Alpha-2 Agonists:

Brimonidine (long-term use), Apraclonidine (IOP spikes)

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous production, increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Lid retraction, respiratory depression (Brimonidine), allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

Contraindications:

Children <2 years

Additional:

Brimonidine: Safest during pregnancy (Category B)

Miotics:

Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Echothiophate

Mechanism:

Stimulates M3 receptors, increasing trabecular outflow

Adverse effects:

Brow pain, miosis, cataract (Echothiophate), retinal tears

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors: (Option C)

Acetazolamide (systemic), Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide (topical)

Mechanism:

Inhibits aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Ciliary edema, secondary angle-closure glaucoma

Osmotic agents: (Option B)

Mannitol (IV), Glycerol (oral)

Mechanism:

Lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient

Adverse effects:

Cardiac overload, urinary retention

questions.text: Which of the following medications should not be administered to a patient with a known case of angle closure glaucoma who has also been diagnosed with major depressive disorder?
questions.explanation:
Anti-Muscarinic
  • Ipratropium bromide, Thiotropium bromide (M1)
  • Toletrodine, Oxybutinin (M3)
  • Scopolamine (M1)

Anti-Histaminics
  • Diphenhydramine, Fexofenadine (H1)
  • Cimetidine, Ranitidine (H2)

Migraine drugs
  • Sumatriptan

Anti-depressants
  • SNRI: Duloxetine and Milnacipram
  • TCA: Amitryptiline

Anti-Epileptics
  • Topiramate, Zonisamide

Antibiotics
  • Trimethoprim-Sulfametoxazole (Cotrimoxazole)

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure?

What is the probable diagnosis for a neonate who presents with symptoms of photophobia and excessive tearing, along with a clinical examination showing a normal tear passage and a clear, but abnormally large cornea, and the presence of Haab's striae in the eye image below?
questions.explanation:
Types
  • Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  • Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  • Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

 

(Buphthalmos: meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.)

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

 

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

questions.text: After an acute episode of angle-closure glaucoma, which triad of symptoms is typically observed?
In which of the following conditions is atropine not recommended for use?
What is the probable diagnosis for an infant brought in with symptoms of excessive tear production, sensitivity to light, and blepharospasm?
questions.explanation:
Primary Congenital Glaucoma

Types

1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. (40% cases)

Typically presents within the first month of life.

Often associated with developmental anomalies of the anterior segment, such as primary congenital glaucoma, which can result from genetic mutations or other congenital conditions.

2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age- Infantile glaucoma is labelled when the disease manifests prior to the child's third birthday

Affects infants older than 1 month and children up to 3 years.

Can also result from genetic factors or be secondary to other conditions like Sturge-Weber syndrome or other syndromic associations.

3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age who develop pressure rise after 3 years but before adulthood. Also known as Juvenile primary open angle glaucoma(POAG) usually occurs between 10 to 35 years of age.

Buphthalmos, meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis: Maldevelopment of the trabeculum and iridotrabecular junction from neural crest cells impairs aqueous outflow, causing elevated IOP.
  • Angle Recess Absence: The angle recess is absent, with the iris inserting either flatly or concavely into the trabeculum.
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features

Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.

Corneal Signs:

  • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
  • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.

Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.

Additional Features:

  • Thin Sclera: Appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue.
  • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
  • Iris Changes: Iridodonesis and atrophic patches in late stages.
  • Lens Changes: Becomes flat and may subluxate.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
  • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
  • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden painful decrease in vision and a fixed, vertically oval pupil. What is the likely diagnosis?

A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the Right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the Left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Phacolytic glau

questions.text: What is the gold standard method for measuring intraocular pressure in patients?
The first line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is?

A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Phacolytic glaucoma B) Malignant glaucoma C) Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis D) Phacomorphic glaucoma

questions.correct_answer: A. Phacolytic glaucoma B) Malignant glaucoma C) Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis D) Phacomorphic glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma (Option D)

Phacolytic Glaucoma (Option A)

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork. 

 

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

questions.text: Please arrange the following ocular medications according to their respective side effects. Column A Column B 1. Amiodarone 2. Digoxin 3. Systemic steroids 4. Hydroxychloroquine A. Retinopathy B. Cataract C. Yellow vision D. Optic neuropathy
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Glau
